|Item_parent=Bacteremia/Fungemia in adults and children
|Item_parent_short=Bacteremia/Fungemia in adults and children
|Rank=A
|Title=Know the general principles of the probabilistic therapeutic management of bacteremia/fungemia
|Description=None
|Topic=Management
|Contributors=
|Order=12}}
- Hospital admission essential

- Antimicrobial = therapeutic emergency

- Choice of antimicrobial: ''probabilistic depending on the suspected clinical route of entry''.

- Parenteral antimicrobial initially

- Bactericide or fungicide

- Combinations (dual therapy) have limited indications, mainly to broaden the spectrum of treatments.

- Antimicrobial treatment is secondarily adapted to :

* Direct examination of blood cultures (Gram stain)
* Species identification
* Antibiotic susceptibility testing / antifungal susceptibility testing

properties.question: When managing bacteremia/fungemia, which of the following is the initial approach for antimicrobial therapy?
properties.option_a: Administering oral antibiotics based on patient's history of allergies
properties.option_b: Choosing a bactericide or fungicide intravenously as a therapeutic emergency
properties.option_c: Selecting antimicrobials based on the most probable clinical route of entry
properties.option_d: Using broad-spectrum antibiotics as a first-line treatment without culture results
